Epstein Plane Passengers: The Manifests Tell Stories

A Boeing 727 seats about 150 people commercially. Epstein's version was configured for private travel, but flight logs show he often wasn't alone. The passenger manifests tell a strange story: world leaders and unidentified women, celebrities and people listed only as "female." These records became crucial evidence in understanding how Epstein operated.

The VIPs: Famous Names in the Logs

Some passengers needed no introduction. Bill Clinton flew extensively with Epstein in 2002-2003, including trips to Africa, Asia, and Europe for Clinton Foundation work. Prince Andrew traveled to Epstein's properties multiple times. Actor Kevin Spacey and comedian Chris Tucker joined Clinton on a 2002 Africa trip. Model Naomi Campbell appears in the logs. These high-profile passengers gave Epstein legitimacy – being seen with former presidents and royalty made him seem acceptable.

The Staff and Employees

Regular passengers included Epstein's personal staff: pilots, household workers, and assistants. Ghislaine Maxwell appears frequently. These weren't casual travelers – they were part of Epstein's operation. The logs show them traveling between his properties in New York, Florida, and the Virgin Islands, maintaining his lifestyle across multiple locations.

The Anonymous Passengers

What investigators found most troubling were passengers listed only by first names or initials. Entries like "Janice," "Eva," or simply "female" appear throughout the logs. Why weren't these passengers fully identified? Standard aviation practice requires full names for manifests. The incomplete records raised immediate questions about who these people were and why their identities were obscured.

Young Women and Girls

Victim testimony has identified some of those anonymous passengers. Virginia Giuffre described being flown on Epstein's planes as a teenager. Other victims have described similar experiences. The combination of partial manifests and victim accounts suggests the anonymous entries may include underage girls transported between Epstein's properties.

Business Associates

Not every passenger was suspicious. Les Wexner and other legitimate business associates appear in the logs. Scientists, academics, and philanthropists traveled to events Epstein funded or organized. These passengers remind us that Epstein maintained genuine business relationships alongside his criminal activities. Distinguishing between the two categories has been a major challenge for investigators.
The passenger manifests paint a picture of two parallel worlds. In one, Epstein traveled with presidents and princes for legitimate philanthropic work. In the other, he transported young women between his properties with minimal documentation. Both worlds existed on the same planes. Understanding who flew with Epstein – and why – remains essential to understanding the full scope of his operations.
